So Consumer Reports can’t recommend the iPhone 4.

And the iPhone 4 is Consumer Reports highest rated smart phone.

I am as excited about getting Consumer Reports highest rated phone today as I was the day it was released. Why?

  1. On the whole, reception is way better than previous iPhones. Many are reporting if they try really hard they can reproduce the problem but in real world use they’re dropping far fewer calls with the iPhone 4 (I should stop right here, it’s all that matters).
  2. The “problem” is 100% solved with a case or small piece of tape (and that’s probably a much bigger piece than what’s actually required).
  3. It’s Consumer Reports highest rated phone. Higher even than Consumer Reports second highest rated phone, the iPhone 3GS, a phone with no reception issue hysteria.

Then there’s the flakey proximity sensor issue the likes of which Garrett Murray is experiencing.

What a fantastic reason to use the hands free headphones and not hold a microwave transmitter next to your brain. Even if the link isn’t clear it’s not worth the risk.

The only thing that frustrates me about these issues is that it’s obviously delaying the iPhone 4’s release in Australia.

It’ll be interesting to see what Apple announces at its Friday press conference.
